Graphical abstract Highlights ► The usage of nickel citrate favoured the formation of small Ni particles within the SBA-15 channels. ► Ni2P favoured the formation of H species on the metal–support interface. ► Commercial silica supported catalysts were more active due to better active phase stability. ► Ni catalysts suffered from deactivation due to active phase agglomeration. ► Chlorine species on Ni2P are labile and easy to remove. Ni and Ni2P based catalysts supported on two different silica supports (Cab-O-Sil commercial silica and SBA-15 mesoporous silica) have been studied in the hydrodechlorination (HDC) of chlorobenzene (CB). Ni catalysts have been prepared from nickel(II) citrate in order to favour the formation of highly dispersed Ni particles. Ni2P based systems have been prepared from a phosphite-type precursor, Ni(HPO3H)2, where a great P excess is present in the catalyst surface. Thus, the role of the active phase, the preparation method and the silica support employed on the activity of the prepared catalysts are detailed. Characterization results reveal that the usage of nickel citrate provides catalysts with a small particle size, regardless of the material support used, although they suffer from deactivation in the HDC reaction due to the agglomeration of the active phase. Ni2P based catalysts prepared from nickel(II) dihydrogenphosphite, also form small particles that are more stable than Ni ones due to the weaker interaction with Cl species and the greater presence of hydrogen spillover species on the support and hydrogen species on the metal–support interface. These hydrogen species in the metal–support interface are ascribed to the P excess present in the catalyst surface. Moreover Cab-O-Sil based catalysts are more active than SBA-ones due to the higher stability of the active phase in the former. Keywords Nickel Nickel phosphide Commercial silica Mesoporous silica SBA-15 Hydrodechlorination Chlorobenzene 1 Introduction Polychlorinated (PCBs) organic compounds have been used commercially since 1930 in the chemical industry as intermediates, insulating, hydraulic and lubricating fluids, heat exchanger or as additives in adhesives and paints [1]. PCBs have found widespread application because of their general stability and inertness as well as their excellent dielectric properties [2]. However, the presence of halogenated organic compounds in effluent discharges is of increasing concern due to the mounting evidence of being adverse for the environment, such as stratospheric ozone, along with the impact on the health, being established as carcinogenic, mutagenic, cumulative in the fatty tissues and chemically stables [3]. It is therefore required a decontamination process to transform these non-desired halogenated organic compounds into less pollutant ones. The legislation imposed by the European Union has become more restrictive, imposing the total elimination from 2010 [4]. Traditionally chlorinated wastes have been removed by incineration and catalytic combustion. In the catalytic combustion PCBs are transformed into CO/CO2 and HCl [5]. However, these processes are problematic due to the incomplete combustion of PCBs leads to highly toxic compounds such as polychlorodibenzodioxins and polychlorodibenzofurans [6]. Moreover, catalysts suffer a strong deactivation associated with the combustion process, increasing the operation costs [7]. Accordingly, considerable efforts are being devoted to develop new technologies to remove polychlorinated organic compounds as ozonation, photolysis, supercritical oxidation, ultrasonic irradiation and electrochemical dechlorination [8–12], although these processes are hampered by practical consideration such as high energy demand and poor efficiency at low contaminant concentrations. In the last decade, the catalytic hydrodechlorination (HDC) received more and more attention. The advantages of catalytic HDC compared to the traditional oxidation strategies are: (a) lower reaction temperature and (b) non-destructive method, whereby halogenated compounds are transformed into reusable hydrocarbons without toxic emissions [2,13,14]. The catalysts used for HDC have mainly been metallic, either monometallic as Ni [15–19], Pd [20–22], Pt [23] and Rh [24] or bimetallic as Pd–Ni [25], Pd–Au [26] and Ni–Au [27], where a synergic effect is observed contributing to the activation of the CCl bond. The use of noble metals limits their implementation to industrial applications because of cost effectiveness. Moreover the usage of noble metals and nickel catalysts presents as disadvantage the deactivation due to surface poisoning by HCl, metal sintering, or/and carbon deposition occluding the active sites. In recent years, a worldwide search for improved catalysts has been undertaken [28]; in this sense, commercial hydroprocessing catalysts, mainly NiMo/Al2O3 and CoMo/Al2O3, have shown high stability and resistance to HCl poisoning in comparison with metal catalysts, due to the electronegativity of sulfur decreases the electronic density of metal [29–31]. Nonetheless, these catalysts require more severe conditions of temperature and H2 pressure to reach high catalytic activity. New approaches have also been taken by using transition metal borides [32,33], carbides [34] and phosphides such as nickel phosphide phases [35–38]. In this sense, in the last decade, transition metal phosphides have attracted great attention as new hydroprocessing catalysts such as hydrogenation (HYD), hydrodesulfurization (HDS) [39–41], hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) [40,42] and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [43], which can be attributed to geometric and electronic factors [44] and their capability to activate hydrogen, and possibly favouring the hydrogen spill-over. In this sense, several researchers have established good hydrogen transfer properties of nickel phosphide species [37,38]. There is an evidence that spill-over hydrogen species contribute to the HDC reaction [18,19,35]. The activity and stability in the HDC reaction is also related to the kind of support used. It this sense, it is well known that alumina and carbon are supports resistant to HCl [4,29,30], maintaining high activity for a long time. With regard to the transition metal phosphides, the role of the support is complex as it affects both the dispersion and the geometric and electronic properties of the active phase as a consequence of the metal–support interaction. The use of acid supports such as γ-Al2O3 leads to a strong interaction with the active phase precursors thus requiring a higher reduction temperature to form the desired phosphide phase [45,46]. Moreover, acid supports also suffer a progressive deactivation by deposition of coke on the catalyst surface. Instead, transition metal phosphides supported over commercial silica show an excellent activity and stability in hydrotreating processes attributed to its good structural stability and resistance to carbonaceous deposition [37], as well as the formation of smaller and stable particles [45,46]. The present work analyzes the formation, activity and catalytic stability of nickel and nickel phosphide catalysts with only 5% of nickel weight supported on Cab-O-Sil commercial silica and SBA-15 mesoporous silica. Ni catalysts have been prepared from citric acid as nickel precursor to promote the formation of highly dispersed Ni particles strongly interacting with the material support and avoiding so the sintering and catalyst deactivation. Ni2P based systems have been prepared from a phosphite-type precursor, Ni(HPO3H)2, where a great P excess is present in the catalyst surface. Thus, the role of the active phase, the preparation method and the silica support employed on the activity of the prepared catalysts is detailed. Moreover, the effect of prolonged exposure of nickel and nickel phosphide based catalysts to concentrated chlorinated aromatic gas streams are examined, particularly in terms of changes in the active phase surface. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The reactants used to prepare the nickel phosphide precursors were phosphorus acid (H2PO3H, Aldrich, 99%), nickel(II) hydroxide (Ni(OH)2, Aldrich 99%). In the case of the nickel based precursors, nickel(II) carbonate hydroxide tetrahydrate (2NiCO3·3Ni(OH)2·4H2O, Aldrich 99%) and citric acid monohydrate (HOC(COOH)(CH2COOH)2·H2O, Aldrich 99%) were employed. The chemical products utilized in the reactivity study were chlorobenzene (Aldrich 99.8%) in hexane (Sigma–Aldrich 99.99%). The gases employed were He (Air Liquide 99.99%), H2 (Air Liquide 99.999%), N2 (Air Liquide 99.9999%) and Ar (Air Liquide 99.99%). 2.2 Catalysts preparation The supports used in this work were commercial silica (Cab-O-Sil M-5, Riedel-de Haen, Sigma–Aldrich) and SBA-15 silica, which was prepared according to the low cost method described elsewhere [47] by using sodium silicate as source of Si. The catalysts were prepared following the incipient wetness impregnation method. Thus, nickel based catalysts (5wt.% Ni) were prepared employing an aqueous solution of nickel(II) citrate. This solution was prepared by mixing nickel(II) carbonate and citric acid in a 2:3 molar ratio and heating at moderate temperature until the solution turned into a bright-green colour. It is well known that the chelated nickel species formed with citric acid lead to a wetted and highly viscous film on the surface of the support giving rise to the formation of very small nickel oxide particles after calcination at 500°C during 4h. The catalyst precursors were reduced at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 from rt. until 550°C, under a hydrogen flow of 100mlmin−1 and maintained for 2h at 550°C [48,49]. On the other hand, nickel phosphide catalysts (5wt.% Ni) were prepared employing an aqueous solution of nickel(II) dihydrogenphosphite (Ni(HPO3H)2). This solution was prepared by mixing the stoichiometric amounts of phosphorus acid (H2PO3H) and nickel(II) hydroxide (Ni(OH)2). The impregnated supports were air dried at 40°C for 24h. Finally, by means of temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) the phosphite precursor was converted into the desired phosphide. For this purpose, the samples were placed in a tubular reactor and reduced under a hydrogen flow of 100mlmin−1 (heating rate of 3°Cmin−1) from rt. to 540°C for Ni2P/SBA-15 and 610°C for Ni2P/SiO2, which was maintained for 2h. These reduction conditions have been chosen according to TPR experiments (vide infra). Thereafter, the prepared catalysts will be referred to as Ni/Cab and Ni/SBA for nickel based catalysts supported on silica Cab-O-Sil and mesoporous silica, respectively; and Ni2P/Cab and Ni2P/SBA for nickel phosphide based catalysts supported on silica Cab-O-Sil and mesoporous silica, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The temperature programmed reduction of phosphite precursor to form nickel phosphide was carried out by placing 80mg of precursor in a tubular reactor, with heating at a linear temperature ramp (3°Cmin−1) in flowing hydrogen (100mlmin−1) from 100 to 800°C. The evolved gases were analyzed in a quadrupole mass spectrometer Balzer GSB 300 02 equipped with a Faraday detector (0–200uma), and the masses 2 (H2), 18 (H2O), 31 (P), 34 (PH3) and 124 (P4) were monitored during the experiment. The signals and temperature were recorded in real time by an online computer. The formation of nickel catalysts from the corresponding oxide precursors were also studied by temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The experiments were carried out between 40 and 800°C, using a H2/Ar (10/90) flow of 40mlmin−1and a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The evolved H2 was analyzed by an on-line chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-14A) provided with a TCD. A cold finger (−80°C) was employed as water tramp. Powder diffraction patterns were collected on an X’Pert Pro MPD automated diffractometer equipped with a Ge(111) primary monochromator (strictly monochromatic Cu-Ka radiation) and an X’Celerator detector. The textural parameters (S BET, V P and d P) were evaluated from the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C as determined by an automatic ASAP 2020 system from Micromeritics. Prior to the measurements, samples were outgassed at 200°C and 10−4 mbar overnight. Surface areas were determined by using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) equation and a nitrogen molecule cross section of 16.2Å2. The total pore volume was calculated from the adsorption isotherm at P/P 0 =0.996. Temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD) was carried out by placing 0.300g of catalyst precursor in U tube reactor where it was firstly reduced in situ according to the experimental conditions above described for both type of catalysts. The catalyst was purged with a He flow (50mlmin−1) at the reduction temperature for 15min, cooled down to 50°C (chemisorption temperature), H2 chemisorption was performed (30mlmin−1) for 1h. After cleaning with Ar (35mlmin−1), the H2-TPD was performed by heating (10°Cmin−1) from rt. to 800°C. The evolved H2 was analyzed by an on-line chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-14A) provided with a TCD. A cold finger (−80°C) was employed as water tramp. Ammonia thermo-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) profiles of catalysts were obtained by placing 0.080g of catalyst precursor into a tubular reactor, where it was firstly reduced in situ. After cleaning with He (35mlmin−1) from rt. to 550°C (10min), and cooling to 100°C, the adsorption of ammonia (5min) at this temperature was performed. A He flow (35mlmin−1) was then passed to eliminate the physisorbed ammonia. Finally, thermoprogrammed desorption was carried out by heating the samples from 100 to 550°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. The evolved ammonia was analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-14A) provided with a TCD. In order to quantify the amount of ammonia desorbed, the equipment was previously calibrated by measuring the corresponding signals of the thermal decomposition of known amounts of hexaaminenickel(II) chloride [Ni(NH3)6]Cl2, supplied by Aldrich. X-ray photoelectron spectra were collected using a Physical Electronics PHI 5700 spectrometer with non monochromatic Mg Kα radiation (300W, 15kV, and 1486.6eV) with a multi-channel detector. Spectra of pelletized samples were recorded in the constant pass energy mode at 29.35eV, using a 720μm diameter analysis area. Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.8eV). A PHI ACCESS ESCA-V6.0 F software package was used for acquisition and data analysis. A Shirley-type background was subtracted from the signals. Recorded spectra were always fitted using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves in order to determine the binding energies of the different element core levels more accurately. Reduced and spent catalysts were stored in sealed vials with an inert solvent. The sample preparation was done in a dry box under a N2 flow, where the solvent was evaporated prior to its introduction into the analysis chamber, and directly analyzed without previous treatment. 2.4 Catalytic test For the catalytic test, the hydrodechlorination reaction of chlorobenzene was chosen, which was performed in a fixed-bed continuous-flow stainless steel catalytic reactor (9.1mm in diameter, and 230mm in length), operated in the down-flow mode. The reaction temperature was measured with an interior placed thermocouple in direct contact with the catalyst bed. The organic feed (0.1mlmin−1) consisted of a solution of chlorobenzene (10wt.%) in hexane that was supplied by means of a Gilson 307SC piston pump (model 10SC). For the activity tests, 0.5g of catalyst was used (particle size 0.85–1.00mm) and was diluted with quartz sand to 3 cm3. Prior to the activity test, the catalysts were reduced in situ as described before. Catalytic activities were measured at different temperatures (250–400°C), at atmospheric pressure of H2, with a flow rate of 60mlmin−1 and WHSV=8.5h−1. Moreover, the stabilities of the catalysts were studied at 325°C for 24h on stream. The evolution of the reaction was monitored by collecting liquid samples after 60min at the desired reaction temperature. These liquid samples were kept in sealed vials and subsequently analyzed by gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-14B, equipped with a flame ionization detector and a capillary column, TBR-14, coupled to an automatic Shimadzu AOC-20i injector). For these catalysts, the main reaction product was benzene (B). For this reason, the total conversion was calculated from the ratio of converted chlorobenzene/initial chlorobenzene. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 Temperature-programmed reduction of precursor catalysts Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out to evaluate the reducibility of the precursors, to understand the phenomena involved in the reduction process and to determinate the optimum reduction conditions prior to the catalytic test. The TPR profiles of Ni-based catalysts are depicted in Fig. 1 A, where it is clearly observed the influence of the material support on the nickel oxide species reducibility. In both cases, two H2 consumption bands are observed. Ni/SBA precursor exhibits a sharp H2 consumption peak centred at 275°C, and a broad and much intense band centred at ca. 500°C. Instead, Ni/Cab precursor presents an initial broad peak located at 325°C and another one more intense centred at 490°C. Both profiles reveal the existence of two kinds NiO oxide precursors. The first one, at low temperature, is due to the reduction of NiO to Ni0 weakly interacting with the material support [48] and possibly forming aggregates; while the second one indicates the presence of NiO species strongly interacting with the support and/or Ni2+ ions interacting with SiO− groups [50]. By comparing both profiles it can be clearly seen that Ni/SBA catalyst presents a much greater proportion of nickel oxide species strongly interacting with the material support and possibly forming small particles mainly located into the channels, however Ni0 particles with a higher particle diameter are also present on the external surface but in a much lesser extend. Ni/Cab sample possesses both types of Ni species, with those reduced at lower temperature in greater proportion than for Ni/SBA sample and reduced in a broader temperature range. Therefore it can be stated that Ni/SBA sample mainly presents small particles highly dispersed on the material support; and Ni/Cab sample also presents small particles, although the proportion of Ni species at lower temperatures are also important suggesting a broader distribution of Ni particles on this sample. In the case of nickel phosphide precursors, the formation of water was followed during the reduction process (Fig. 1B). The curves corresponding to the evolved H2O for the reduction of the precursors have been described in previous works [46]. Both catalysts show an initial peak at temperatures below 375°C that arises from physically adsorbed water desorption, and it is related to the hygroscopic character of the nickel(II) dihydrogenphosphite precursor salt and the support itself [46]. Moreover, during the reduction of Ni2P/SBA precursor the formation of water curve shows a main peak centred at 540°C, while for Ni2P/Cab precursor, this maximum is centred at 610°C with a small shoulder at 450°C. These results indicate a stronger interaction of the precursors over silica Cab-O-Sil, and therefore the possible formation of smaller Ni2P particles over this support. The band at higher temperature is due to the reduction of nickel and phosphorous species to form the corresponding Ni2P phase [46]. A previous study, that used in situ X-ray diffraction to follow the reduction of a phosphorus-poor Ni composition, showed that Ni was reduced at low temperatures, and subsequent phosphidation did not occur until moderate temperatures [51]. The PH3 formation during the reduction of the phosphite (not shown) also shows a two-peak pattern, but with the second peak smaller, probably due to capture of the PH3 to form the phosphide. According to these experiments the selected reduction temperature was 550°C for Ni/Cab and Ni/SBA-15. In the case of nickel phosphide catalysts, the maxima of the curves of evolved water detected by the mass spectrometer were chosen to be the reduction temperatures in the synthesis of larger quantities of catalysts, being 540°C for Ni2P/SBA-15 and 610°C for Ni2P/SiO2. The catalysts were kept at the reduction temperature for 2h to ensure a complete reduction, followed by cooling to rt. under helium flow of 60mlmin−1. 3.1.2 X-ray diffraction XRD diffractograms were used to identify the crystalline phases formed after the reduction process. Fig. 2 shows the diffractograms of reduced catalysts. All the catalysts show a broad diffraction line located at 2θ =23°–25°, typical of amorphous silica. The diffraction patterns of nickel catalysts (Fig. 2A) present two diffraction peaks located at 2θ =44.5° and 51.8° ascribed to the presence of Ni0 (JCPDS No.: 01-070-1849). These signals are not well defined in accordance to H2-TPR patterns, which pointed to small Ni particles present on both catalysts. On the other hand, the diffraction patterns corresponding to nickel phosphide-based catalysts (Fig. 2B) exhibit diffraction lines located at 2θ =40.7°, 44.6°, 47.4° and 54.2° typical of Ni2P phase (JCPDS No.: 01-089-4864). As observed for Ni-based catalysts, the intensity of these signals depends on the support employed, with the catalyst supported on mesoporous silica (Ni/SBA) presenting much more intense diffraction peaks. The particle size of the active phases of the studied catalysts determined by applying the Scherrer equation to the main diffraction line, 2θ =40.7°, reported a particle size of 38nm for Ni2P-5/SBA-15 while for Ni2P-5/Cab it cannot be determined due to the bad-defined diffraction peak. From these data and in accordance to H2-TPR experiments, Ni catalysts present a similar dispersion of the active phase, while Ni2P ones show a lower dispersion of the active phase when supported on mesoporous silica in spite of its higher surface area. Previously, a better Ni dispersion has been attained over Cab-O-Sil than over MCM-41 mesoporous silica [52], what suggest that SBA-15 mesoporous silica favours a greater dispersion of Ni phase than MCM-41 counterpart, due to the higher pore diameter of the former. Instead, for Ni2P phase similar results have been obtained previously [45], indicating that P excess seems to affect the mesoporous structure in a way that could hinder the preferential location of Ni2P phase into the channels and therefore, diminishing the active phase dispersion. In order to evaluate the possible influence of metals incorporation and reduction on SBA structure, XRD patterns at low angles of both catalysts, Ni/SBA and Ni2P/SBA, were performed (data not shown). In both cases, the diffraction line characteristic of d 100 crystallographic plane of SBA-15 material is observed, indicating the maintenance of mesoporous structure after catalyst preparation. 3.1.3 Textural properties The textural properties were evaluated from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C. The corresponding isotherms are represented in Fig. 3 and the textural values compiled in Table 1 . Regardless of the material support employed a decrease in both S BET and pore volume is observed in all cases for the reduced catalysts with regard to the pristine supports. It is Ni2P/SBA-15 supported catalyst that suffering a greater loss of both surface area and pore volume due to the possibly blockage of mesoporous structure by P species and the consequent formation of larger particles. These large particles should be located at the external surface of SBA-15 material and probably blocking the mouth of the mesopores. With regard to supported catalysts on commercial silica, both catalysts suffer a decrease in the surface area and pore volume, although the reduction is much less marked. N2–adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 3B) hardly change after catalyst preparation, only a decrease in the adsorbed volume is observed at higher relative pressures, ascribed to nitrogen adsorbed in Cab-O-Sil interparticles. The incorporation of phosphorus does not provoke the great decrease in the textural properties as observed in SBA-based catalysts. The presence of interparticle porosity could be the responsible for the lower effect in the textural properties of Cab-O-Sil supported catalysts. 3.1.4 Thermo-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) H2-TPD measurements were used to get insights into the interactions between hydrogen species and the catalyst surface. This is an interesting point to consider in order to understand the catalytic behaviour of these systems in the HDC reaction. The H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The TPD profiles show two main peaks. The first one below 350°C, corresponding to the desorption of hydrogen from metallic surfaces, and the second one centred at around 600°C, which is assigned to the desorption of hydrogen species spilled over on the supports [36] and distant from the metallic particles. Moreover, there is also a desorption band between these two peaks, and seen as a shoulder of the first desorption peak originated by hydrogen desorbed from chemisorption sites located at the metal–support interface [53]. By comparing Ni and Ni2P catalysts it can be clearly seen that Ni2P systems chemisorb a greater amount of hydrogen, accounting from the greater signals intensity. Metallic nickel catalysts desorb the hydrogen mainly at low temperatures, pointing to a lower spill-over capability of these catalysts with regard to Ni2P ones, in accordance with other authors [36]. However, Ni2P based catalysts prepared by our synthetic approach, present higher hydrogen chemisorbed quantities than Ni-based ones at both low and high temperatures. These results are contrary to those reported by Liu et al. [36], who observed a very low amount of hydrogen species on the surface of Ni2P phase prepared with a Ni/P atomic ratio of 1/1. Our results strongly indicate that the P/Ni atomic ratio affects the H2 chemisorption capability of the corresponding nickel phosphide catalyst. The phosphorous excess seems to increase the amount of H2 chemisorbed on the Ni2P surface and Ni2P–support interface. The greater amount of hydrogen spill over species on Ni2P catalysts is due to the interaction of dissociated hydrogen species with Ni–P bridges is weaker than with Ni–Ni [54], since nickels atoms present a residual positive charge in Ni2P phase. Moreover, other authors have pointed that the presence of phosphorus species in the form of P–OH favours the hydrogen spill-over [38]. Therefore, the diffusion of dissociated hydrogen species front the metallic surfaces towards the support is easier in the case of Ni2P catalysts. Besides, Ni2P/Cab possesses a great amount of hydrogen coming from both Ni2P surface and hydrogen chemisorption sites located at the metal–support interface, which could play an important role in the catalytic activity of these catalysts, as suggested by Keane and Tavoularis [28]. Considering the influence of the support on the H2 chemisorption capability of these systems, the amounts of hydrogen desorbed are lesser when the used support is Cab-O-Sil. The interaction with hydrogen depends on the particle size and therefore with the electronic density of the particles, thus lower particles presenting a lower electronic density interact in a weaker way with hydrogen species. Ni2P particles are smaller on Cab-O-Sil and explain the lower H2 chemisorption capability with regards to Ni2P/SBA one. Instead, the greater H2 chemisorption capability on Ni/SBA catalyst can be due to the Ni species reduced at low temperature, H2-TPR sharp reduction peak at 275°C, that are ascribed to higher Ni particles. 3.1.5 Acidic properties The acidic properties of the catalysts were measured by thermo-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) between 100 and 550°C. Table 1 compiles the total amount of NH3 desorbed for supports and catalysts. As expected, the total acidity of the catalysts is higher than those corresponding to the supports. The acidity of nickel catalysts have been assigned in the literature to be due to coordinative unsaturated Ni2+ sites acting as a kind of new Lewis acid centres. Ni/SBA catalyst presenting a greater proportion of smaller particles probably located in the inner of the porous structure which are more difficult to reduce, as seen form TPR experiments and accounts for the higher acidity presented by this sample. In the case of the nickel phosphide catalysts, the acidity has been assigned to both Lewis and Brönsted active sites. The presence of Lewis sites have been ascribed to nickel species bearing a small positive charge due to the electron transfer from nickel to phosphorous [55], while the Brönsted acidity is associated to the presence of PO–H species. Moreover, in the preparation of these catalysts, nickel(II) hydrogenphosphide is used, presenting a high excess of phosphorous species which remain after the reduction process. The strength of the acid sites can be determined by the temperature at which the adsorbed NH3 starts to desorb. Thus, the amounts of ammonia desorbed from 300 to 550°C are due to medium–strong acid sites. As seen in Table 1, the total acidity for catalysts supported on SBA-15 is higher than those for supported on Cab-O-Sil, while the strong acidity is much higher for Ni catalysts, regardless of the material support. 3.1.6 XPS In order to investigate the surface composition of fresh and spent catalysts, XPS measurements were carried out. Table 2 compiles the Ni 2p 3/2 and P 2p 3/2 binding energy values of fresh and spent catalysts. The Ni 2p core level spectra present in all cases two contributions: the first one centred at 853.1eV is assigned to Ni0 for nickel catalysts (Fig. 5 A) [56] and/or Ni δ+ forming Ni2P phase, in the case of nickel phosphide catalysts (Fig. 5B) [46]. The second one with a binding energy value of ca. 856.5eV is attributed to unreduced Ni2+ species forming mainly NiO in the case of nickel based catalysts and Ni(HPO3H)2 for nickel phosphide based ones, along with the broad shake-up peak at approximately 6.0eV above the Ni2+ species, characteristic of nickel divalent species. The binding energy of Ni in the Ni2P phase is very close to that of Ni metal, so it cannot be discarded the presence of metallic nickel in Ni2P-based catalysts. By comparing the influence of the support on the Ni 2p core level spectra (Fig. 5A), it is seen a less intense Ni 2p core level signal for Ni/SBA catalyst, explained as the preferential location of Ni species inside the channels without being detected by the XPS technique [57]. Instead, no important differences are observed in the Ni 2p core level spectra of nickel phosphide catalysts. The P 2p core level spectra for nickel phosphide catalysts prepared from phosphite method show three contributions (not shown). The contribution appearing at lower binding energy values (128.6eV) and assigned to reduced phosphorus in the form of nickel phosphide, P δ−. The peak at 133.4eV is due to unreduced (HPO3H−) species. Finally, the contribution at 134.9eV arises from phosphate species (PO4 3−) due to a superficial oxidation of phosphide to phosphate due to air contact [41,46]. A greater surface phosphorous enrichment is observed in the case of Ni2P/SBA catalyst and confirmed by the surface Ni/P atomic. This ratio is 0.21 and 0.19 for Ni2P/Cab and Ni2P/SBA, respectively, far from the theoretical ratio of 2, reflecting a surface phosphate enrichment due to the excess of phosphorus species used to form the precursor salt. 3.2 Catalytic results The catalytic properties of nickel and nickel phosphide catalysts were assayed in the HDC reaction of chlorobenzene. Fig. 6 A depicts the HDC conversion as a function of the reaction temperature for all the catalysts; the experimental results correspond to conversions after 60min at each temperature. At lower temperatures, Ni/Cab catalyst shows the lowest conversion, possibly there is an induction period for this catalyst or perhaps its degree of reduction increases during the catalytic test leading thus to a higher conversion when the reaction temperature increases and the reaction time is higher. At 300–325°C Ni2P/Cab catalyst is the most active one. The higher catalytic activity for Ni2P catalysts has been reported previously [36] and ascribed to the physicochemical properties of nickel phosphides and greater amounts of spillover hydrogen. Nevertheless, at 375°C all catalysts reach similar conversion levels, being the Ni2P/Cab the most active one, with a conversion close to 100%. In the HDC of chlorobenzene over transition metal catalysts several aspects must be taken into account. It is reported in the literature the role of spillover species on the HDC performance [20,58], since these spill-over species play the role of cleaners of chlorine ions from the catalyst surface [59]. The higher activity of Ni2P versus Ni is related to the physicochemical properties of nickel phosphide phase. It is well described that nickel atoms in Ni2P structure possess a small positive charge and therefore a lower electronic density diminishing the interaction with the electron acceptor chlorine species. Moreover it is described the “ensemble-effect” of phosphorous, decreasing the number of Ni exposed atoms. Therefore both the electronic density and geometrical location of nickel atoms help to diminish the interaction nickel–chlorine and promoting the ulterior desorption of chlorine as HCl with hydrogen species coming from spillover on the support [36]. In this sense, a much greater amount of H2-spillover species has been detected over these catalysts, as deduced from H2-TPD experiments, which contribute to their higher HDC activities. Ni2P catalysts prepared by this new method present a greater amount of hydrogen released from the metal–support interface. Therefore, the lower interaction of chlorobenzene with Ni2P along with the close proximity of spill-over species in the Ni2P–support interface seems to be determinant to explain the higher activity Ni2P-based catalysts. The importance of these metal–support interface species has been previously considered by Keane and Tavoularis [28]. Considering the influence of the material support, Ni2P/Cab turns out to be more active than Ni2P/SBA and could be due to the higher amount of H-spillover species in the metal–support interface due to the lower particle size of the former. On the other hand, the activity presented by nickel catalysts depends on the support employed and on the reaction temperature. At temperatures lower than 300°C, Ni/SBA is more active than Ni/Cab, at higher temperatures both of them present similar conversion values. It could be the higher H2 chemisorption capability of Ni/SBA catalyst the responsible for the better results obtained at lower temperatures. The stability of this set of catalysts was evaluated for 26h at 325°C (Fig. 6B). Except Ni/SBA, in general all the catalysts maintain their activities during 8–10h on stream, although catalysts undergo a gradual deactivation with higher reaction times. Metallic nickel based catalysts show higher deactivation after 26hours on stream. In contrast, Ni2P catalysts only suffer from little deactivation after 14h of reaction. Thus, after 26h Ni2P/SiO2 catalyst maintains 90% of conversion, whereas Ni2P/SBA-15 exhibits 74% conversion. The loss of activity with time on-stream has been ascribed to coke deposition, the formation of surface metal halides and/or metal sintering [2]. The deactivation by coke is directly related to catalyst acidity; while the deactivation by the formation of surface metal halides and/or metal sintering strongly depends on the interaction of halide species with the active phase. In this sense the electronic density of the metal will govern the interaction with chlorine species since this atom is an electron acceptor and therefore the higher the electronic density of the metal the higher the chlorobenzene transformation into a Cl-free molecule [36]. The deactivation by coke should be discarded as long as the carbon content of spent catalysts are in all cases lower than 3wt.%. This is expected due to the soft conditions employed in the catalytic test, i.e., low temperature and normal pressure. The factors responsible for catalysts deactivation have been elucidated by XRD, TEM and XPS analysis of spent catalysts in order to gain further insight into the possible active phase modification. In the case of nickel-based catalysts, XRD of spent catalysts after the stability test were carried out. Fig. 2A compares the X-ray diffractograms for fresh and spent catalysts. It can be observed how the intensities of Ni0 diffraction peaks increase and therefore the particle sizes calculated from Scherrer equation changes during the test. Thus if fresh catalysts presented a particle size lower than 5nm (detection limit of XRD technique), the particle size of spent catalysts were of ca. 75nm in both cases. In this sense, Menimi et al. [60] has established that the presence of hydrogen chloride induces an appreciable agglomeration of the nickel crystallites attributed a surface mobility of Ni–Cl species [61]. The superficial NiCl2 with bridges of chlorine between particles is reduced again under the experimental conditions of the catalytic reaction giving rise to the agglomeration of metallic nickel particles, diminishing the metallic dispersion and occluding the active metal faces. This fact may be responsible, at least in part, for the dramatic loss of hydrodechlorination activity observed for Ni-based catalysts. In fact, TEM analysis for fresh and spent Ni/SBA catalyst (Fig. 7 ) clearly shows this process, where the fresh catalyst shows the presence of very small particles located inside the channels, while after the catalytic process the presence of aggregates is clearly detected. The analysis of the spent catalyst by EDAX indicated the presence of Cl, with a Ni/Cl atomic ratio of 4.4, far from the 0.5 ratio expected if NiCl2 compound is formed. Therefore, only the superficial Cl incorporation seems to occur. XPS analyses of spent Ni catalysts are included in Fig. 5, whereas the binding energy values and atomic ratios are summarized in Table 2. The Ni 2p signal (Fig. 5A) shows an increase in the relative intensity of the band attributed to Ni0 phase (∼853.3eV), and in a greater way for Ni/SBA catalyst. This is due to the migration and agglomeration process taking place during the catalytic test, as it has been mentioned in the discussion of XRD and TEM data of spent catalysts. As explained before, this migration is governed by the formation and subsequent reduction of NiCl2. Thus, the incorporation of Cl on the catalyst surface has been clearly observed from the analysis of the Cl 2p signal for spent catalysts. This contribution located at about 199.1eV is attributed to chlorine species in the form of NiCl2 [62]. The presence of chlorine is again detected for both Ni catalysts (Fig. 8 ) and in a greater proportion over Ni/SBA sample presenting a surface Ni/Cl atomic ratio of 1.02 (Table 2), higher than the theoretical value of 0.5 for NiCl2, and far from bulk value obtained from EDAX analysis and confirming the superficial incorporation of Cl species. This fact is explained through the mechanism of this reaction where two steps are prominent in the HDC reaction: the interaction of chlorobenzene (1) and/or the reaction with hydrogen chloride as by-product (2) with the metal surface forming nickel chloride (chlorination); and (3) the regeneration of the nickel surface by hydrogen (hydrogenation). There is a competition between the reduction and the poisoning mechanism (chlorination) both depending on the structure of the catalyst and reaction conditions [63]. The Ni–Cl interaction depends on the bonded site, being the particle size an important factor to consider since the higher the particle size the higher the electronic density and therefore the stronger the Ni–Cl interaction. Ni/SBA sample retains a higher amount of Cl on its surface as observed from XPS analysis, so the regeneration of the catalyst should be more difficult leading to Ni–Cl species that also induces the growth of the nickel crystallites with a dramatically decrease of available active sites. Since the particle size in both Ni catalysts is quite similar and the active phase agglomeration is also quite similar over both of them, the interaction with Cl species is the clue to understand the lower activity of Ni/SBA catalyst, where the regeneration occurs in a lesser extent possibly due to a stronger Cl–Ni interaction. These data reveal that Ni particles on Cab-O-Sil support are much more stable and resistant to Cl-poisoning. The proposed mechanism has been verified through the following experiment: a sample of NiCl2 (5wt.% Ni) was supported on Cab-O-Sil type silica, dried at 60°C, and directly employed as a catalyst in the same experimental conditions, i.e., at 325°C during several hours. The found results are represented in Fig. 9 . It is observed that after the first hour on stream this sample is quite active in HDC of chlorobenzene, rising 54% of conversion. It means that under the experimental conditions the NiCl2 salt was reduced forming metallic nickel which is active in such a reaction. When the reaction proceeds the conversion suffers a monotonically decay confirming that HCl evolved in the reaction reacts again with the metallic nickel forming the pristine salt. XRD pattern of this spent catalyst shows intense diffraction peaks due to the Ni0 phase, with a particle size of 50nm. Therefore the dynamic process of NiCl2 reduction and subsequent HCl caption from Ni0 provokes a particle agglomeration with time on stream that reduces the number of active sites and therefore decreases the catalyst activity in this reaction. That is why the deactivation of Ni catalysts is a dynamic process based on the alternative formation of NiCl2 and its ulterior reduction into Ni0 with a higher agglomeration of particles than the former. Taking into account that chlorobenzene must be adsorbed on the catalyst surface by the chlorine atom and adopting a more o less perpendicular orientation (that planar orientation must be discarded since the by-product of the reaction is always benzene) the decrease in the conversion with the increment of Ni crystallites is only due to the disappearance of active sites as a consequence of nickel agglomeration. Finally, the study of nickel phosphide spent catalysts, which were much more stable than Ni ones, revealed that the diffractograms for spent samples (Fig. 2B), hardly suffer modification compared with the fresh ones, which means that the active phase does not suffer modification during the catalytic test, and accounts for the higher stability of these catalysts. XPS analyses of these spent catalysts show that the Ni 2p core level spectra for nickel phosphide catalysts (Fig. 5B) suffer a decrease in the intensity of the contribution assigned to Ni2P, discarding the formation of Ni2P phase or migration and agglomeration phenomena during the catalytic test, which corroborates the previous discussion, based on the XRD results. It can be deduced that Ni2P crystallites have strong anti-sintering properties, as it was already observed [36]. This decrease in the intensity of the contribution due to the Ni2P phase could be ascribed to the incorporation of chloride into Ni2P structure. The physicochemical properties of nickel phosphide catalysts reveal two sites of adsorption: Ni hollow sites where the adsorption is strong and Ni–P bridge sites where the adsorption is weaker [64]. Therefore it can be suggested that chlorine incorporated into the nickel phosphide phase is bonded over Ni–P sites susceptible to hydrogenolysis and removal as HCl. In this sense, the incorporation of chlorine in the Ni2P phase during the catalytic test was detected by XPS analysis of spent catalysts, where a Cl 2p band at around 199.0eV is observed in both cases (Fig. 8), although in a much lesser extend than for Ni-based catalysts. The explanation of its excellent behaviour with time on stream could suggest the formation of a superficial phosphochloride specie NiP x Cl y as active phase, analogous to the phosphosulfide phase described in the hydrodesulfurization reaction (HDS) by Ni2P supported catalysts [65]. Therefore the higher activity and stability of Ni2P based catalysts are due to the higher lability of Cl species formed on its surface. A similar analysis than that performed with NiCl2/Cab was performed by mixing NiCl2 +H2PO3H and supported on Cab-O-Sil type silica, but no activity was observed, indicating both neither Ni2P phase formation occurs under the experimental conditions employed nor NiCl2 reduction into Ni0 takes place under the presence of phosphorous acid. 4 Conclusions Ni and Ni2P supported catalysts have been evaluated in the HDC reaction of chlorobenzene, by using different silica-type support. Ni2P based catalysts are more active than Ni ones, since Ni catalysts undergo deactivation due to the agglomeration of the active phase as a consequence of NiCl2 formation and subsequent reduction under the experimental conditions employed. The usage of nickel(II) citrate as nickel precursor salt favours the formation of small particles possibly strongly interacting with the material support due to the high reduction temperature required. The better activity and stability observed for Ni2P based samples are ascribed to both the presence of higher H2 spill-over species on the support and H2 species on the metal–support interface, along with the lower interaction of Cl species with Ni2P. Over these catalysts, Cl is more labile to be removed and the presence of H in the close proximity favours Cl-remotion from the catalyst surface. The influence of the material support on the Ni and Ni2P based catalysts properties reveals that regardless of the active phase, Cab-O-Sil commercial silica provides highly stable particles undergoing a lower agglomeration process in the case of Ni catalysts and a lower incorporation of Cl in the case of Ni2P ones. Therefore the higher activity and stability of Ni2P based catalysts is due to the higher lability of Cl species formed on its surface, which possibly are forming a “phosphochloride” phase similar to the phosphosulfide phase observed in the HDS reaction with these phosphides. coredata.dc:description: Ni and Ni2P based catalysts supported on two different silica supports (Cab-O-Sil commercial silica and SBA-15 mesoporous silica) have been studied in the hydrodechlorination (HDC) of chlorobenzene (CB). Ni catalysts have been prepared from nickel(II) citrate in order to favour the formation of highly dispersed Ni particles. Ni2P based systems have been prepared from a phosphite-type precursor, Ni(HPO3H)2, where a great P excess is present in the catalyst surface. Thus, the role of the active phase, the preparation method and the silica support employed on the activity of the prepared catalysts are detailed. Characterization results reveal that the usage of nickel citrate provides catalysts with a small particle size, regardless of the material support used, although they suffer from deactivation in the HDC reaction due to the agglomeration of the active phase. Ni2P based catalysts prepared from nickel(II) dihydrogenphosphite, also form small particles that are more stable than Ni ones due to the weaker interaction with Cl species and the greater presence of hydrogen spillover species on the support and hydrogen species on the metal–support interface. These hydrogen species in the metal–support interface are ascribed to the P excess present in the catalyst surface. Moreover Cab-O-Sil based catalysts are more active than SBA-ones due to the higher stability of the active phase in the former.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the silica support on the activity of Ni and Ni2P based catalysts in the hydrodechlorination of chlorobenzene. Study of factors governing catalyst deactivation
